main: ^Looks like a warehouse of sorts. This must be where they receive supplies for the lab.
^It must be on a different floor.
^But there isn't a button for higher floors here, only down...
^Then the elevator must be controlled through some sort of signal rather than a button. Let's look around.

main.#: quest:talk to the group of robots

ciphers: ^Dammit, I can't understand what they're saying! Long Dusk's communications are all encrypted!
^*sigh* Looks like it's time to teach you about ciphers.
^Ciphers encode text in a way that makes it impossible for someone to read it without the secret key.
^This makes communication secure, so you can share your secrets without anyone learning them.
^Does that mean we will never be able to get to the other floors? I guess that's mission failed, we'll get 'em next time...
^Not so fast! It looks like these robots use a substitution cipher called Caesar cipher for their messages.
^Yeah, you're in luck - this cipher is quite easy to break!
^Let me explain some cipher terminology to you first - you have to know your enemy before you can defeat it.
^Perfect! Now, the message "What kind of sentence?" is currently not encoded, and we call that PLAINTEXT.
^This screen should help you understand the cipher.
^Feel free to play around with it using your arrow keys.
^Now we can pick a random number between 1 and 26. This will be our ENCRYPTION KEY. Let's say the key is 4.
^Why is it between 1 and 26? Can we not change that range?
^That's because the Caesar cipher works by shifting the plaintext alphabet by a certain number of letters.
^Since there are 26 letters in the english alphabet, a key of more than 26 will wrap around back to the start of the alphabet.
^This will be equivalent to starting counting from 0 again, so it makes no sense to have a key bigger than 26.
^Also, a key of 0 is the same as not encrypting the plaintext, since the plaintext and ciphertext
^alphabets will be the same, in other words there will be no offset.
^So how do we use this key then?
^The encryption key will encode the plaintext into gibberish that no one can understand.
^The encoding process is called ENCRYPTION and the resulting encoded text is called CIPHERTEXT.
^Since our key is 4, to encrypt the plaintext we need to replace each plaintext letter with the letter 4 places to the right from it in the
^For example, the letter A will be replaced with E, because E is 4 places down the alphabet.
^But the first letter of our plaintext is W!  W - X - Y - Z, that's only 3 hops and the alphabet has ended. How will that
^This is where the wrapping comes into play! We treat the alphabet like a loop rather than a finite line, so once you reach the end
^you hop right back to the start.
^Does that mean that W will become A because A is at the start of the alphabet?
^Yes, exactly! Because we only needed to hop one more place after Z, the letter W will map to the letter A. If you needed to encode
^the letter Y with the key of 4, which letter will it become?

continue: ^Because we need to do 4 hops from Y, Y - Z - A - B - C will land on C, so the letter Y will be encoded to become the letter C.
^Now that you understand the Caesar cipher, let's encrypt our plaintext "What kind of sentence?".
^Huh? It has the name Alex in it, what does that mean?
^Haha, it doesn't actually mean anything. It just so happened that encrypting the word "What" with a key of 4 transformed it into
^You will likely find lots of other plaintexts and keys that result in curious ciphertexts on your encryption journey.
^You say that as if I will need to know about encryption outside of this quest.
^Actually, yes you will! When you interact with computers, encryption is all around you.
^Most computer communications these days are encrypted.
^For example, when you access the internet your search queries are encrypted so that no one can listen in on what weird
^Not just your search queries, but also any personal information you enter on websites through forms.
^Your username and password, your credit card details, your address etc.
^Encryption keeps you safe from identity theft and hacking.
^Oh, do they all use Caesar cipher?
^No, they use much more advanced ciphers that are really hard to break.
^The Caesar cipher is very insecure! They're susceptible to brute force and frequency analysis attacks.
^Wait, you said "most communications" and not "all". How can I know if my internet activity is being encrypted?
^There's one easy tip for that: look out for links that start with "https".
^Those are encrypted, and the "s" in "https" stands for "secure".
^Some links start with "http". Those websites do not encrypt your activity, so be careful about what you type on there!
^You can also look for a closed padlock icon somewhere on your URL bar.
^Conversely, an open padlock icon means the website isn't using encryption.
^Ah, so now I know why my browser gave me an open padlock warning when I wanted to download free Cavebuild...
^Then why did you ignore it? Warnings are meant to be followed, it's a measure to keep you safe!
^I wanted to get Cavebuild for free!
^People like you are the reason humans aren't a Type II civilisation yet!
^Let's go intercept a message from one of the robots and I will teach you how to break this cipher!
^We need to find the cipher key to access the elevator again.

decrypt: ^Looks like this robot is talking to the door.
^Let's see if we can send an encrypted message to the door pretending to be the robot asking to open it.
^Don't we need to know the encryption key that the robot and door share if we want to pretend to be the robot?
^That's correct, we will first have to figure out the key.
^Let's listen in on what the robot is saying!
^That sounds like a different language! How will we manage to find the right key to decipher this?
^We could perform a brute force attack!
^Haha, no, there will not be any physical violence involved.
^A BRUTE FORCE ATTACK uses trial and error to find the correct answer, in this case the encryption key.
^We will try to use every possible key to find the correct key for this cipher, and decrypt the message.
^If the resulting plaintext looks like a normal sentence, then we know we found the key.
^I think I understand that, but what exactly does decryption mean?
^DECRYPTION is simply converting ciphertext to plaintext. It's just another word for decoding an encoded message.
^Together, an encryption algorithm and a decryption algorithm make up a CIPHER.
^For a brute force attack, we don't need to know the Caesar Cipher decryption algorithm.
^But if we did, how would we do it?
^We just have to shift the alphabet the key number of places, but in the opposite direction!
^Alright, so how do we perform the brute force attack?
^First, you will need to remember how many possible keys an English Caesar cipher has.

continue: ^Because the Caesar cipher performs alphabetic shifts, it has as many possible keys as letters in the English alphabet.
^Remember, you can't shift a letter by more steps than the number of letters in the alphabet! Otherwise it will just wrap back to 0
^It's the Bruce wheel! It's short for brute force wheel. I just made that name up.
^You can use the left and right arrow keys to rotate the wheel.
^Each sector on the wheel represents a Caesar cipher key.
^You can perform a brute force attack by trying out each key on the wheel until the message looks like real words.
^That will mean you found the right key. Press enter to check your answers.

^This means that every letter in the original message was shifted to the letter

^After a few rounds of the brute force attack, you're gonna find a command that deals a lot of damage.
^Sit back and enjoy those few seconds of accomplishment, but keep in mind that you will have to keep trying commands again until
